Accidental Release Prevention
Berry Petroleum Cogeneration Facility 38 has developed a Risk Management Program to address the Risk Management Plan (RMP) requirements (40 CFR Part 68).  Berry Petroleum Cogeneration Facility 38 is extremely diligent in the handling of all chemicals and is dedicated to the safety of its employees and the neighboring community. Berry Petroleum Cogeneration 38 staff is highly trained and utilizes modern equipment to monitor the facility and provide safeguards, while effectively and safely using ammonia for controlling NOx emissions. 

Berry Petroleum Cogeneration Facility 38 has a long standing commitment to worker and public safety. This commitment is demonstrated by the resources invested in accident prevention, such as personnel training and consideration of safety in the design, operation, and maintenance of the Ammonia Injection System.  Berry Petroleum Cogeneration Facility 38A?s policy is to implement reasonable controls to prevent foreseeable releases of regulated substances. 

Stationary Source and Regulated Substance
Berry Cogeneration Facility 38 is located in Kern County, California, approximately 3.2 miles southwest of the City of Taft and 3.2 miles northwest of the City of Maricopa. The facility is adjacent to the State Route 33 Highway, approximately one mile west of Route #33. The site occupies 1.8 acres. The site is adjacent to the Berry Petroleum Company Production Facilities. The area around the facility is basically uninhabited. 

Berry Petroleum Cogeneration Facility 38 is owned by Berry Petroleum Company.  Steam and electricity are produced and sold to the local power utility company. The facility consists of a single Frame-VI General Electric Gas Turbine (rated capacity 38 MW), a heat recovery steam generator (HRSG) including auxiliary duct burner rated at 300,000 pounds per hour of steam, and associated auxiliary and balance of plant systems.  Exhaust heat from the gas turbine is recovered in the heat recovery ste

am generation system. All steam produced is delivered to the Berry Petroleum Company for injection into the oil formation for enhanced oil recovery.

The site is currently operated by Solar Assets Management Services and is manned 24 hrs a day. There are five personnel assigned to the facility - (1) Lead Technician and (4) Technician-II personnel.

The regulated substance managed at the Facility is anhydrous ammonia.  The maximum intended inventory is 54,720 lbs of anhydrous ammonia and it is stored in a pressurized horizontal storage tank at ambient temperature in liquid form.  When ambient conditions do not significantly promote the vaporization of liquid ammonia, a vaporizer is utilized to heat the liquid to its boiling point to produce vapor. The vapor ammonia is sent to a mixing chamber where it is mixed with air. The resulting vapor ammonia / air stream is then injected into the HRSG. This, in conjunction with the catalyst within the HRSG, allow for the reduction of NOx and other unwanted materials being sent to the environment. The exhaust gas containing a lower concentration of NOx is then sent from the HRSG to an exhaust stack. 

Hazard Assessment Summary/Offsite Consequence Analysis
Worst-Case Release Scenario Results Summary
Scenario Description: Per the EPA RMP Regulations, one worst-case analysis has been defined and modeled for the ammonia injection system.  The results can be found in the Hazard Assessment documentation located behind the Hazard Assessment Tab 2 of the CalARP/RMP Submittal Binder.

Alternative Release Scenario Results Summary
Scenario Description: Two alternative release scenarios were modeled. The results can be found in the Hazard Assessment documentation located behind the Hazard Assessment Tab 2 of the CalARP/RMP Submittal Binder.

Risk Considerations
Although the storage and use of anhydrous ammonia has inherent potential risks, and worst-case release scenarios can potentially reach the community; Berry Petroleum Cogeneration Fac

ility 38 has recognized these potential risks and structured its safety programs to make the worst case type of event non-credible.  In addition to the safety practices of the company and plant personnel to make this worst-case event non-credible, it should also be recognized that there are inherent analysis assumptions that make the results of the atmospheric dispersion analysis appear worse than what would actually be expected during such an event (e.g., In the event of a release, sudden rupture and flashing of ammonia would be highly turbulent. Turbulence causes entrainment of air and the released vapor dilutes much more quickly than is shown in the model).

In addition to the use of conservative analysis assumptions that over-predict the effects of a potential release, other characteristics of the facility and site serve to minimize the potential risks associated with an ammonia release:

A?Automatic / Manual Shutdown
A?Well Designed Relief System

The history of the Berry Petroleum Cogeneration Facility 38 (i.e., no RMP-applicable ammonia releases) reflects the adequacy of the design and diligence of the plant staff in safely operating the Ammonia Injection System.

Accidental Release Prevention Program 
As part of the implementation of this CalARP Program, key Prevention Program elements were documented and implemented by Berry Petroleum Cogeneration Facility 38 to manage process safety issues associated with the use of ammonia for the NOx abatement system.  In addition, common industry standards, policies, and procedures are currently utilized to ensure safe practices are being performed.

The facilityA?s maximum intended inventory of anhydrous ammonia is 54,720 lbs.  Therefore, the covered process has over the 10,000 lbs threshold quantity for EPA RMP and Cal/OSHA PSM threshold quantities and over the 500 lbs state threshold for California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program.  As a result, the anhydrous ammonia covered process is subject to CalARP

Program Level 3, EPA RMP Program Level 3 and Cal/OSHA PSM.

The Anhydrous Ammonia Prevention Program 3 elements include:

A?Process Safety Information
A?Process Hazard Analysis
A?Operating Procedures
A?Training
A?Mechanical Integrity
A?Management of Change
A?Pre-Startup Safety Review
A?Compliance Audits
A?Incident Investigation
A?Employee Participation
A?Hot Work Permit
A?Contractors

In addition, key emergency response elements were addressed in the Business Emergency Plan. See EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM below.

Five-Year Accident History
There have been no RMP-applicable releases of ammonia at Berry Petroleum Cogeneration Facility 38 in the past five years.

Emergency Response Program
Neither Berry Petroleum Cogeneration Facility 38 nor Solar Turbines are First Responders.  Employees are trained to evacuate and call 911 in case of an emergency.  Berry Petroleum Cogeneration Facility 38 will coordinate with local Fire Department and First Responders. Berry Petroleum Cogeneration Facility 38 has filed a Business Emergency Plan to help coordinate with local responders.

An Emergency Action Plan (EAP) that meets the requirements of the CCR Title 8 A?3220 is in place.

Planned Changes To Improve Safety
The Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) study has been conducted to examine mitigation measures to improve safety at the facility.  Planned changes to improve safety are listed as recommendations in the May 29th, 2009 PHA Report.  Any outstanding recommendations will be addressed by December 2009.

Flammables: Worst Case
The use of flammable materials at Berry Petroleum Cogeneration Facility 38 is not encompassed by either the federal or state RMP requirements.  Therefore, this section is not applicable.

The use of flammable materials at Berry Petroleum Cogeneration Facility 38 is not encompassed by either the federal or state RMP requirements.  Therefore, this section is not applicable.
